chapter: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question: Question 1: What is the corneal epithelium normally composed of?
questions.explanation:
The corneal epithelium is made up of stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium. 141 
Sold by @itachibot Layers of the cornea: • Epithelium (Stratified squamous non-keratinized epithelium) • Bowman’s membrane - Acellular; does not regenerate • Stroma (Thickest layer) - The stroma can scar, but cannot regenerate • Dua’s layer (Newly discovered, toughest layer) • Descemet’s membrane- Ends peripherally as Schwalbe’s ring; has regenerative potential • Endothelium (Most metabolically active layer)- does not regenerate Note: Limbal stem cells are located at the corneoscleral limbus, in the palisades of Vogt. 
Deficiency may result in chronic epithelial defects and "conjunctivalization" of the cornea
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 2: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the hydration and transparency 
of the cornea?
questions.explanation:
The hydration level and transparency of the cornea is maintained mainly by the endothelial 
cells of the cornea. The endothelium possesses Na+/K+ ATPase, which keeps the corneal stroma in a relatively 
dehydrated state. This helps maintain corneal transparency. Endothelial cells decrease in number 
with age. If the cornea becomes overhydrated, it begins to scatter light and gradually begins to 
lose its transparency Other factors contributing to the transparency of the cornea are as follows: • Regular arrangement of corneal lamellae (Maurice theory) • The peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae (Goldmann theory) • Avascularity of the cornea • A balance between the intraocular pressure (IOP) and swelling pressure The different layers of the cornea are as follows: • Epithelium • Bowman’s membrane • Stroma (substantia propria) • Dua’s layer (pre-Descemet’s layer) • Descemet’s membrane • Endothelium
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question: Question 3: What is the average density of corneal endothelial cells?
questions.explanation:
The density of corneal endothelial cells in adults is about 2500–3000 cells/mm². 142 
Sold by @itachibot Variation in corneal endothelial density with age: • At birth- 3,500–4,000 cells/mm2 at birth • Young adults- 2500–3000 cells/mm² • Old age (about 80 years)- 2000 cells/mm² Corneas stored in eye banks are assessed for their quality and viability using a variety of 
parameters. Donor tissues are screened for stress lines, mechanical trauma, scarring, corneal 
edema, and infiltrates that could indicate poor tissue quality. They are further evaluated for 
thickness and endothelial cell density (a surrogate for endothelial function) which are important 
determinants of successful graft transplantation. Endothelial cell density (ECD) and morphology are assessed using a specular microscope or by a 
bright-field/phase-contrast light microscope. Note: The number of cells decreases at about 0.6% per year, and the neighboring cells enlarge to 
fill the space as the cells cannot regenerate. At a density of about 500 cells/mm2, corneal edema 
develops and transparency is impaired. This is known as critical endothelial density.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question: Question 4: Below what horizontal diameter can a diagnosis of micro-cornea be made?
questions.explanation:
To make a diagnosis of microcornea, in this child, the diameter of the cornea should be less than 
10 mm. Micro-cornea • Horizontal corneal diameter is 10 mm or less (over 2 years of age) or less than 9 mm (in the 
newborn). • There may be hypermetropia and a shallow anterior chamber but other dimensions are normal. Megalocornea • Horizontal corneal diameter is 12 mm or more (up to 2 years of age) or 13 mm or more (if age 
>2 years) • There is typically high myopia and astigmatism, but normal corrected visual acuity. • Usually X-linked recessive; 90% of affected individuals are male. Cornea plana • The cornea is flatter than normal, i.e., the radius of curvature is larger. • There is a corresponding reduction in refractive power, resulting in high hypermetropia. Keratectasia • It is characterized by a protuberance between the eyelids caused by a severely opacified, and 
sometimes vascularized, cornea. • It is often associated with raised intraocular pressure as well as intrauterine keratitis. • Usually unilateral Microphthalmos 143 
Sold by @itachibot • Microphthalmia is a condition in which the entire eye is small, with an axial length at least two 
standard deviations below the mean for age. • It may or may not be associated with ocular dysgenesis. Nanophthalmos • In nanophthalmos (simple microphthalmos), the entire eye is small, but is structurally normal; • It is usually associated with hypermetropia and strabismus Anophthalmos: Anophthalmos (anophthalmia) refers to the complete absence of any visible globe 
structure.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following organisms are capable of invading the intact cornea?
questions.explanation:
Gonococcus can invade an intact cornea. Organisms that can penetrate the intact epithelium of the cornea can be remembered with the 
mnemonic- CHaNNeLS • Corynebacterium diphtheria • Haemophilus influenza;Haemophilus aegypticus • Neisseria gonorrhea; Neisseria meningitidis • Listeria • Shigella
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient with a history of uncomplicated cataract surgery 1 year back, presents with pain, 
redness, and purulent discharge from his right eye. A greyish-white serpiginous ulcer was 
noted over the lower third of the cornea. The anterior chamber showed a 4 mm hypopyon and 
a moderate flare reaction. A smear from the ulcerated area is likely to demonstrate which of 
the following organisms?
questions.explanation:
Hypopyon corneal ulcer with a characteristic serpiginous description (ulcus serpens) is typically 
caused by Pneumococcus. The bacterial hypopyon is sterile. Ulcus serpens is a greyish-white or yellowish disc-shaped ulcer occurring near the centre of the 
cornea. The ulcer has a tendency to creep over the cornea in a serpiginous fashion. Risk factors include both surgical and non-surgical ocular trauma, dry eye, chronic corneal 
disease, immune alterations and contact lenses. An examination may reveal the following signs: • Swelling of lids and blepharospasm • Conjunctival hyperemia • Ciliary congestion, hypopyon and anterior chamber flare reaction • Iridocyclitis Image given below shows ulcus serpens. 144 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 7: A young woman presents with sudden onset, rapidly progressing ocular pain, photophobia, 
and blurred vision in her right eye for 1 day. A deep, 4 mm diameter corneal ulcer, 
surrounded by stromal infiltrates was visualized. The anterior chamber has small amounts of 
mucopurulent discharge. She mentions using a cosmetic contact lens which she forgot to 
remove before sleeping 2 days ago. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.explanation:
The sudden onset and rapid progression of ocular symptoms and ulceration in this patient along 
with the history of improper contact lens usage are suggestive of a Pseudomonas infection. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common gram-negative organism isolated from corneal 
ulcers and is a frequent cause of contact lens–associated keratitis. Other risk factors include 
chlorinated swimming pools, hot tubs, ventilators, nebulizer, and vaporizer solutions, and 
ophthalmic solution bottles. Pseudomonas keratitis has a rapid and fulminant course if left untreated and are associated with a 
worse visual prognosis than that caused by most other common bacterial 
pathogens. Pseudomonas spp. can cause corneal perforation in just 48 hours. Treatment is mainly 
by topical NSAIDs and topical antipseudomonal antibiotic eye drops such as tobramycin 1.3% and 
fluoroquinolone eye drops.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 8: A young woman comes with sudden onset ocular pain, tearing, and photophobia in the left 
eye. You suspect a bacterial corneal ulcer. What concentration of cephazolin drops would you 
prescribe for this patient?
questions.explanation:
The concentration of fortified cephazolin used to treat uncomplicated bacterial keratitis is 5% ( 50 
mg/mL) Treatment of uncomplicated bacterial keratitis: • Antibiotic eyedrops (broad-spectrum) • If not responding, fortified antibiotic eye drops are used • Fortified cephazolin (5%) • Fortified tobramycin (1.3%) • Fortified vancomycin (5%) 145 
Sold by @itachibot • Cycloplegic drugs- Preferably 1% atropine eye ointment or drops to prevent pain due to ciliary 
spasm. Also, it prevents the development of posterior synechiae. • Oral vitamin A and vitamin C help in the healing of the epithelium • Systemic analgesics and anti-inflammatory drugs Management of non-healing ulcers: • Debridement • Chemical cauterization- 10–20% trichloroacetic acid, carbolic acid • Conjunctival flapping Management of impending perforation: • Decrease intraocular pressure (IOP) by antiglaucoma drugs • Tissue adhesive glue such as cyanoacrylate • Bandage contact lens • No strain
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 9: A non-sterile hypopyon is seen in 
.
questions.explanation:
Fungal keratitis can cause non-sterile hypopyon. Unlike bacterial ulcer, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungi can penetrate into the anterior 
chamber without perforation. Aspergillus spp. are the most common cause. Hypopyon in a fungal ulcer is fixed, non-sterile and contains fungal filaments.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 10: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, 
resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. What would be the most 
likely pathology? 134 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette of the patient presenting with pain, photophobia, and redness of the 
eye following trauma by a vegetative matter is suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. Fungal corneal ulcer also known as mycotic keratitis is usually caused by trauma from vegetative 
matter such as branches of trees, leaves and animal tails. Injudicious use of topical steroids and 
antibiotics increases the predisposition to develop secondary fungal keratitis. Mycotic keratitis can be caused by • Filamentous fungi such as Aspergillus and Fusarium • Yeasts such as Candida and cryptococcus • Dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma and Blastomyces Typically in fungal corneal ulcers, the signs are more prominent than the symptoms. The 
symptoms of fungal keratitis are similar to that of bacterial ulcers which include pain, 
lacrimation, photophobia, blurred vision, and redness of the eyes. 146 
Sold by @itachibot A typical fungal ulcer has the following signs: • Greyish white looking dry corneal ulcer with rolled out margin. • Feathery finger-like extensions into the corneal stroma under intact epithelium • Wessley ring which is a sterile immune ring that occurs due to the deposition of immune 
complexes • Multiple small satellite lesions around the ulcer • Hypopyon: The hypopyon in fungal ulcer is immobile and unsterile unlike bacterial ulcer (sterile 
hypopyon) • Perforation is rare • Corneal vascularization is usually absent. A diagnosis of fungal ulcer is made by a typical history of trauma with vegetative matter followed 
by clinical examination and KOH mount or SDA agar cultures from corneal scrappings. The image below depicts a fungal corneal ulcer with the arrowhead indicating a satellite lesion. Other options: Option A: Anterior uveitis is the inflammation of the uveal tissue from the iris up to the pars 
plicata of the ciliary body. Infectious uveitis can be caused by the exogenous entry of the 
organisms following penetrating injuries, perforation of corneal ulcer, and post-intaocular 
operations. Acute anterior uveitis presents with symptoms of pain, photophobia, lacrimation, blurring of 
vision and redness of the eye. Signs of anterior uveitis include: • Aqueous flare - It is the earliest sign of acute anterior uveitis, it occurs following the leakage of 
protein particles into the aqueous humor. • Keratic precipitates(KP) - These are pathognomonic for anterior uveitis. They are proteinaceous 
cellular deposits at the back of the cornea arranged in a triangular fashion. These include mutton 
fat KP's as seen in granulomatous uveitis and granular KP's of non granulomatous uveitis. 147 
Sold by @itachibot • Iris nodules: typically occur in granulomatous uveitis. Koppe's nodules are at the pupillary 
border and Busacca's nodules are situated near the collarette. Option C: Conjunctivitis is the inflammation of the conjunctiva of which the bacterial 
conjunctivitis is the most common. Acute bacterial conjunctivitis is characterized by marked 
conjunctival hyperemia, swelling of the conjunctiva(chemosis), edematous eyelids, sticking 
together of lid margins and mucopurulent discharge from the eye. The image shows a patient with bacterial conjunctivitis. Option D: Corneal laceration: Partial corneal laceration or lamellar corneal laceration occurs from 
a blunt trauma and is treated by patching and antibiotics.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 11: A farmer presents with blurring of vision in his left eye. He has a history of injury with a bush 
to the same eye while working. An ulcer is seen in his cornea with feathery margins. Slit-lamp 
examination shows infiltrates in the corneal stroma in a circular fashion. Which type of 
hypersensitivity reaction causes these infiltrates?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical situation points towards a fungal corneal ulcer and the infiltrates of stroma in a 
circular fashion are suggestive of the immune ring of Wessely. This immune ring is due to type 3 
hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex). The immune ring of Wessely can be made out as a deep stromal haze in a slit lamp. It occurs as a 
result of the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the stroma. Once deposited it draws the 
immune cells, inciting further inflammation. The given shows an ulcer in the cornea and the adjacent immune ring of Wessely. 148 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question: Question 12: What is the characteristic feature of a fungal ulcer?

options.b: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescien dye

questions.explanation:
Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer. The signs of a fungal ulcer include: • Irregular margins of the ulcer. • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer. • An immune ring (Wesseley) may be seen around the ulcer due to deposition of the immune 
complexes. • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation. • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, immobile due to the direct invasion of 
the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 13: Steroids are contraindicated in 
.
questions.explanation:
Steroids are contraindicated in fungal corneal ulcer Steroids make the fungi facultative pathogens when they are otherwise symbiotic saprophytes. 
Therefore, the use of these drugs predisposes the patients to fungal infections and perforation.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 14: 135 
Sold by @itachibot A 41-year-old female presented with a one-month history of photophobia and foreign body 
sensation in her right eye. A slit-lamp examination showed a corneal ulcer. The culture of the 
corneal scrapings grew a filamentous organism identified as a fusarium species. What would 
be the drug of choice in this case?
questions.explanation:
This patient with a one-month history of eye foreign body sensations and photophobia and slit 
lamp exam showing an ulcer that had fusarium growth most likely has a fungal corneal ulcer. 
Natamycin 5% suspension is the drug of choice for filamentous fungal keratitis caused by 149 
Sold by @itachibot fusariam species. Surface debridement is also done as it helps to remove slough, reduce the load of infection and 
enhances drug penetration. Amphotericin B is particularly effective against yeasts but less 
effective against filamentous fungi. Also, its penetration through an intact epithelium is less than 
natamycin. Amphotericin B is the first agent of choice against yeasts. Amphotericin B (0.15%) drops can be 
considered alone or in combination with natamycin in refractory cases. Treatment of specific fungal corneal ulcers: Topical antifungal drops • Aspergillus and Fusarium- Natamycin 5%, amphotericin B, fluconazole (0.2%) • Candida- Amphotericin B (0.15%) or econazole (1%) Systemic antifungals such as itraconazole and voriconazole are used for severe non-responding 
cases or if the location of the ulcer is near the limbus or if there is a risk of perforation leading to 
endophthalmitis.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not a feature of the given condition?
questions.explanation:
The above image shows a dendritic ulcer caused by herpes simplex virus. Corneal guttata are not 
seen in HSV infection. They are droplet-like accumulations of non-banded collagen on the 
posterior surface of Descemet's membrane. It is a feature of corneal dystrophies.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 16: Which of the following statements is true about the given condition? 136 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It is related to Hutchinson’s triad
options.b: There is usually a history of primary HSV infection as a child
options.d: High dose topical acyclovir is the treatment of choice

questions.explanation:
The image shows a unilateral painful, vesicular rash suggestive of herpes zoster ophthalmicus 
(HZO) caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV) within the ophthalmic 
nerve. Neurotrophic keratitis is a complication of HZV infection. Keratitis occurs due to corneal nerve damage by the virus leading to decreased sensation, frequent 
infections, persistent epithelial defect, thinning and even perforation. Corneal lesions in HZO (zoster keratitis): • Epithelium- superficial punctate keratitis and pseudo-dendritic ulcer • Stroma- nummular keratitis and disciform keratitis Other ocular lesions in herpes zoster: • Uveitis • Episcleritis and scleritis • Conjunctivitis • Acute retinal necrosis • Secondary glaucoma 150 
Sold by @itachibot • Anterior segment necrosis and pthisis bulbi Other options: Option A: Hutchinson’s rule is related to herpes zoster ophthalmicus. It states that if the tip of the 
nose is involved, there will be a significant risk of ocular involvement. This is due to the 
involvement of the nasociliary nerve. Hutchinson's triad is seen in congenital syphilis. Option B: There is primary HZV infection (chickenpox/varicella) not HSV infection. Option D: Systemic acyclovir is the treatment of choice; not topical antiviral drops. Oral acyclovir 
800 mg five times a day for 7-10 days, ideally initiated within 72 h of the onset of symptoms is the 
usual regimen. The image shows Hutchinson's sign in a patient with herpes zoster ophthalmicus.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 17: A 17-year-old boy presented with blurred vision, photophobia, and increasing pain in his right 
eye. He has been using contact lenses for the past 2 years. He mentions swimming with his 
cousins 2 weeks back in a local pond. A close-up image of the eye is given below. What is the 
most likely explanation? 137 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The history of a patient with contact lens use with swimming in freshwater ponds with the image 
depicting a ring lesion (stromal infiltrate) makes acanthamoeba keratitis the likely diagnosis. Acanthamoeba keratitis is a rare protozoal infection of the cornea. It is more common in soft 
contact lens users. The organism exists either as active, motile trophozoites or dormant, 
double-walled cysts. Suspicious sources of infection can be swimming or use of the hot tub while 
wearing contact lenses, homemade saline solution to wash contact lenses, exposure to standing 
groundwater etc. Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion. It presents as ring 
lesion (most common), pseudo-dendrites and as a reticular pattern. Diagnosis: • Confocal microscopy - may reveal bright trophozoites with pseudopodia in the basal epithelium 
and double-walled cyst forms 151 
Sold by @itachibot • Histopathology - double-walled cysts are seen on H&E. Other stains 
for Acanthamoeba include calcofluor white, acridic orange, Giemsa-Wright, Wheatly trichrome or 
periodic acid-Schiff • Culture - Acanthamoeba can be grown on a bed of E. coli plated on a non-nutrient agar
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 18: A 39-year-old contact lens user with a corneal ulcer, showing no improvement to tobramycin 
drops, was referred to a tertiary care centre. Corneal biopsy revealed double-walled cysts 
within the stroma. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation:
This patient with a corneal ulcer whose biopsy showed double walled cysts in the stroma most 
likely has acanthamoeba keratitis. Polyhexamethylene biguanide (PHMB) is the treatment of 
choice for acanthamoeba keratitis. Combination therapy with chlorhexidine is most effective against trophozoites and cysts. This is 
recommended as the first line of therapy. Other topical anti-amoebic agents: • Diamidines- Propamidine isethionate (0.1 %), Hexamidine • Aminoglycosides- Neomycin, Paramomycin • Imidazoles- Clotrimazole, Miconazole
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following does not cause interstitial keratitis?
questions.explanation:
Diphtheria is not a cause of interstitial keratitis. Interstitial keratitis is a non-ulcerating, inflammatory reaction of the corneal stroma that is 
characterized by non-suppurative infiltration and often stromal vascularization. The epithelium 
and endothelium are not affected. Scarring due to stromal inflammation and vascularization, in 
interstitial keratitis, can result in decreased vision. Interstitial keratitis (IK) is a common endpoint of any keratitis that predominantly involves the 
corneal stroma. So there is a wide range of potential etiologies. Treatment for IK typically involves the use of topical corticosteroids, as well as appropriate 
systemic medications for the associated systemic disease. Immune-mediated etiologies

questions.question:
Question 20: Which of the following infections is classically associated with salmon patch appearance of 
the cornea?
questions.explanation:
Salmon patch appearance of the cornea is classically associated with syphilitic infection. This is because, syphilis causes deep vascularization of the cornea, leading to a radial bundle of 
brush-like vessels. Stages of interstitial keratitis in congenital syphilis: • Progressive stage - ground-glass appearance • Florid stage - salmon patch appearance • Stage of regression - ghost vessels
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 21: 138 
Sold by @itachibot A patient with recurrent corneal epithelial erosions is diagnosed with limbal stem cell 
deficiency. She has been enrolled on a research trial for corneal epithelial stem cell 
transplant. All are markers that can be used to identify stem cells from an ex-vivo culture 
except?
questions.explanation:
Connexin 50 is not a limbal stem-cell marker. The major markers proposed for epithelial stem cells can be categorized into at least three groups: • Nuclear proteins such as transcription factor p63 • Cell membrane or transmembrane proteins • Integrins (integrin ß1, 6, and 9), • Receptors (epidermal growth factor [EGF] receptor and transferrin receptor CD71) • Drug-resistance transporters (ABCG2—a universal stem cell marker) • Cytoplasmic proteins such as • Cytokeratins (cytokeratin 14 - exclusively at LSC) 153 
Sold by @itachibot • Alpha-enolase
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 22: For her final year thesis, an ophthalmology resident is studying endothelial cell loss due to 
phacoemulsification surgery. The image is taken during the pre-op evaluation of one of the 
cataract patients. What does this show?
questions.explanation:
The given image is a specular microscopy view of endothelial cells of different shapes 
(pleomorphism) and large surface area (polymegathism). These are indicators of endothelial 
dysfunction. A normal endothelium has a regular hexagonal shape. Because these cells are terminally 
differentiated cells, they do not divide, and when they die, the remaining cells have to stretch to 
cover more area, resulting in polymegathism and pleomorphism. Taking an endothelial cell count can be helpful before taking patients up for cataract or refractive 
surgery so that any potential endothelial dysfunction or thinning is recognized before they have 
the surgical intervention.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 23: Which of the following is not a feature of herpetic keratitis? 139 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Corneal guttata are seen in corneal dystrophy. Peripheral guttata are seen in old age—Hassall–Henle bodies. Central guttata, on the other hand, 
are found in Fuch's endothelial dystrophy.
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 24: A corneal foreign body was removed from a 53-year-old man. He was sent home with 
chloramphenicol and steroid eye drops. Two days later he came back with a corneal ulcer and 
a hypopyon. The ulcer scraping under microscopy revealed branched septate hyphae. What is 
the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given history of trauma and worsening with antibiotic-steroid drops suggests a fungal corneal 
ulcer. Out of the given options, Aspergillus is the fungus with branched septate hyphae. Clinically, fungi are classified on a morphological basis into filamentous, yeast, and 
dimorphic forms: • Filamentous organisms are multicellular with branched hyphae. It can be septate or aseptate. • Septate filamentous organisms, such as Fusarium and Aspergillus, have hyphae that are divided 
by cell walls. • Non-septate filamentous fungi, include Mucor and Rhizopus. • Yeasts, such as Candida and Cryptococcus, are unicellular fungi that reproduce by budding, but 
in tissue, they might develop elongated buds (pseudohyphae). • Dimorphic fungi such as Histoplasma, Coccidioides, and Blastomyces demonstrate both a yeast 
phase that occurs in tissues and a mycelial phase that appears on culture media and saprophytic 
surfaces. Image: Branched septate hyphae of Aspergillus spp. 154 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Basics of Cornea and Infectious Keratitis

questions.question:
Question 25: Corneal sensation is lost in 
.
questions.explanation:
Corneal sensation is lost in herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. The pathognomic feature of viral keratitis is decreased corneal sensation. Decreased corneal 
sensation is also seen in diabetes mellitus and leprosy. 155 
Sold by @itachibot Non-infectious Disorders of Cornea
